question: The horizontal component of Earth's magnetic field at a place is <katex>$3\times10^{-5}T$</katex>. If the dip at that place is <katex>$45^{\circ}$</katex>, the resultant magnetic field at that place is
explanation: The horizontal component <katex>$B_H = B \cos \delta$</katex>. Given <katex>$B_H = 3 \times 10^{-5} T$</katex> and <katex>$\delta = 45^{\circ}$</katex>, we have <katex>$B = \frac{B_H}{\cos 45^{\circ}} = \frac{3 \times 10^{-5}}{1/\sqrt{2}} = 3\sqrt{2} \times 10^{-5} T$</katex>.
